sections.title: Syntax
sections.raw_content:
A beginStatement is:

  begin
    statementsAndDeclarations
  end

sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: A begin statement limits the scope of declarations made within it to the confines of the begin/end block. In Turing, begin is rarely used, because declarations can appear wherever statements can appear, and because every structured statement such as if ends with an explicit end.
sections.mdown_content: A **begin** statement limits the scope of declarations made within it to the confines of the **begin/end** block. In Turing, **begin** is rarely used, because declarations can appear wherever statements can appear, and because every structured statement such as **if** ends with an explicit **end**.

sections.title: Example
code:
begin
            var bigArray : array 1 .. 2000 of real
             bigArray will exist only inside this begin statement
        end

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: In Pascal programs, begin statements are quite common because they are required for grouping two or more statements, for example, to group the statements that follow then. This is not necessary in Turing as where ever you can write a single statement, you can also write several statements.
sections.mdown_content: In Pascal programs, **begin** statements are quite common because they are required for grouping two or more statements, for example, to group the statements that follow **then**. This is not necessary in Turing as where ever you can write a single statement, you can also write several statements.
